trans-unit.source: Manage DNS record sets and records on Azure DNS | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Manage DNS record sets and records on Azure DNS | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Managing DNS record sets and records on Azure DNS when hosting your domain on Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: Managing DNS record sets and records on Azure DNS when hosting your domain on Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: All PowerShell commands for operations on record sets and records.
trans-unit.target: All PowerShell commands for operations on record sets and records.

trans-unit.source: How to manage DNS records
trans-unit.target: How to manage DNS records

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.SELECTOR]
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.SELECTOR]

trans-unit.source: Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: Azure Powershell
trans-unit.target: Azure Powershell

trans-unit.source: This guide will show how to manage record sets and records for your DNS zone.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show how to manage record sets and records for your DNS zone.

trans-unit.source: It is important to understand the distinction between DNS record sets and individual DNS records.
trans-unit.target: It is important to understand the distinction between DNS record sets and individual DNS records.

trans-unit.source: A record set is the collection of records in a zone with the same name and the same type.
trans-unit.target: A record set is the collection of records in a zone with the same name and the same type.

trans-unit.source: For more details, see [Understanding record sets and records](dns-getstarted-create-recordset.md#Understanding-record-sets-and-records).
trans-unit.target: For more details, see [Understanding record sets and records](dns-getstarted-create-recordset.md#Understanding-record-sets-and-records).

trans-unit.source: Create a record set
trans-unit.target: Create a record set

trans-unit.source: Record sets are created using the `azure network record-set create` command .
trans-unit.target: Record sets are created using the `azure network record-set create` command .

trans-unit.source: You need to specify the record set name, the zone, the Time-to-Live (TTL) and the record type.
trans-unit.target: You need to specify the record set name, the zone, the Time-to-Live (TTL) and the record type.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The record set name must be a relative name, excluding the zone name.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The record set name must be a relative name, excluding the zone name.

trans-unit.source: For example, the record set name ‘www’ in zone ‘contoso.com’ will create a record set with the fully-qualified name ‘www.contoso.com’.
trans-unit.target: For example, the record set name ‘www’ in zone ‘contoso.com’ will create a record set with the fully-qualified name ‘www.contoso.com’.

trans-unit.source: For a record set at the zone apex, use "@" as the record set name, including quotation marks.
trans-unit.target: For a record set at the zone apex, use "@" as the record set name, including quotation marks.

trans-unit.source: The fully-qualified name of the record set is then equal to the zone name, in this case "contoso.com".
trans-unit.target: The fully-qualified name of the record set is then equal to the zone name, in this case "contoso.com".

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS supports the following record types: A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, NS, SOA, SRV, TXT.
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS supports the following record types: A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, NS, SOA, SRV, TXT.

trans-unit.source: Record sets of type SOA are created automatically with each zone, they cannot be created separately.
trans-unit.target: Record sets of type SOA are created automatically with each zone, they cannot be created separately.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] CNAME record sets cannot co-exist with other record sets with the same name.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] CNAME record sets cannot co-exist with other record sets with the same name.

trans-unit.source: For example, you cannot create a CNAME with the relative name ‘www’ and an A record with the relative name ‘www’ at the same time.
trans-unit.target: For example, you cannot create a CNAME with the relative name ‘www’ and an A record with the relative name ‘www’ at the same time.

trans-unit.source: Since the zone apex (name = ‘@’) always contains the NS and SOA record sets created when the zone is created, this means you cannot create a CNAME record set at the zone apex.
trans-unit.target: Since the zone apex (name = ‘@’) always contains the NS and SOA record sets created when the zone is created, this means you cannot create a CNAME record set at the zone apex.

trans-unit.source: These constraints arise from the DNS standards, they are not limitations of Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: These constraints arise from the DNS standards, they are not limitations of Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: Wildcard records
trans-unit.target: Wildcard records

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS supports [wildcard records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildcard_DNS_record).
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS supports [wildcard records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildcard_DNS_record).

trans-unit.source: These are returned for any query with a matching name (unless there is a closer match from a non-wildcard record set).
trans-unit.target: These are returned for any query with a matching name (unless there is a closer match from a non-wildcard record set).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To create a wildcard record set, use the record set name "\*", or a name whose first label is "\*", e.g. "\*.foo".
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To create a wildcard record set, use the record set name "\*", or a name whose first label is "\*", e.g. "\*.foo".

trans-unit.source: Wildcard record sets are supported for all record types except NS and SOA.
trans-unit.target: Wildcard record sets are supported for all record types except NS and SOA.

trans-unit.source: Get a record set
trans-unit.target: Get a record set

trans-unit.source: To retrieve an existing record set, use `azure network dns-record-set show`, specifying resource group, zone name, record set relative name and the record type:
trans-unit.target: To retrieve an existing record set, use `azure network dns-record-set show`, specifying resource group, zone name, record set relative name and the record type:

trans-unit.source: List record sets
trans-unit.target: List record sets

trans-unit.source: You can list all records in a DNS Zone using `azure network dns-record-set list` command:
trans-unit.target: You can list all records in a DNS Zone using `azure network dns-record-set list` command:

trans-unit.source: Option 1
trans-unit.target: Option 1

trans-unit.source: List all record sets.
trans-unit.target: List all record sets.

trans-unit.source: This will return all record sets, regardless of name or record type:
trans-unit.target: This will return all record sets, regardless of name or record type:

trans-unit.source: Option 2
trans-unit.target: Option 2

trans-unit.source: List record sets of a given record type.
trans-unit.target: List record sets of a given record type.

trans-unit.source: This will return all record sets matching the given record type (in this case, A records):
trans-unit.target: This will return all record sets matching the given record type (in this case, A records):

trans-unit.source: In both cases you will specify the resource group name and zone name.
trans-unit.target: In both cases you will specify the resource group name and zone name.

trans-unit.source: Add a record to a record set
trans-unit.target: Add a record to a record set

trans-unit.source: Records are added to record sets using the `azure network dns-record-set add-record`.
trans-unit.target: Records are added to record sets using the `azure network dns-record-set add-record`.

trans-unit.source: The parameters for adding records to a record set vary depending on the type of the record set.
trans-unit.target: The parameters for adding records to a record set vary depending on the type of the record set.

trans-unit.source: For example, when using a record set of type 'A' you will only be able to specify records with the parameter "-a `<IPv4 address>`".
trans-unit.target: For example, when using a record set of type 'A' you will only be able to specify records with the parameter "-a `<IPv4 address>`".

trans-unit.source: The following examples show how to create a record set of each record type containing a single record.
trans-unit.target: The following examples show how to create a record set of each record type containing a single record.

trans-unit.source: Create A record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create A record set with single record

trans-unit.source: To create record set, use `azure network dns-record-set create`, specifying resource group, zone name, record set relative name, the record type and time to live (TTL):
trans-unit.target: To create record set, use `azure network dns-record-set create`, specifying resource group, zone name, record set relative name, the record type and time to live (TTL):

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If --ttl parameter is not defined, the value defaults to 4 (in seconds).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If --ttl parameter is not defined, the value defaults to 4 (in seconds).

trans-unit.source: After creating the A record set, add IPv4 address to record set with `azure network dns-record-set add-record`:
trans-unit.target: After creating the A record set, add IPv4 address to record set with `azure network dns-record-set add-record`:

trans-unit.source: Create AAAA record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create AAAA record set with single record

trans-unit.source: Create CNAME record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create CNAME record set with single record

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] CNAME records only allows one single string value.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] CNAME records only allows one single string value.

trans-unit.source: Create MX record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create MX record set with single record

trans-unit.source: In this example, we use the record set name "@" to create the MX record at the zone apex (e.g. "contoso.com").
trans-unit.target: In this example, we use the record set name "@" to create the MX record at the zone apex (e.g. "contoso.com").

trans-unit.source: This is common for MX records.
trans-unit.target: This is common for MX records.

trans-unit.source: Create NS record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create NS record set with single record

trans-unit.source: Create SRV record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create SRV record set with single record

trans-unit.source: If creating an SRV record in root of zone, just specify _service and _protocol in the record name—there is no need to also include ‘.@’ in the record name
trans-unit.target: If creating an SRV record in root of zone, just specify _service and _protocol in the record name—there is no need to also include ‘.@’ in the record name

trans-unit.source: Create TXT record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create TXT record set with single record

trans-unit.source: Modifying existing record sets
trans-unit.target: Modifying existing record sets

trans-unit.source: This is shown by the following examples:
trans-unit.target: This is shown by the following examples:

trans-unit.source: Update a record in an existing record set
trans-unit.target: Update a record in an existing record set

trans-unit.source: For this example we will add another IP address (1.2.3.4) to an existing A record set (www):
trans-unit.target: For this example we will add another IP address (1.2.3.4) to an existing A record set (www):

trans-unit.source: You will use `azure network dns-record-set delete-record` to remove an existing value from a record set:
trans-unit.target: You will use `azure network dns-record-set delete-record` to remove an existing value from a record set:

trans-unit.source: Remove a record from an existing record set
trans-unit.target: Remove a record from an existing record set

trans-unit.source: Records can be removed from a record set using `azure network dns-record-set delete-record` Note that the record being removed must be an exact match with an existing record, across all parameters.
trans-unit.target: Records can be removed from a record set using `azure network dns-record-set delete-record` Note that the record being removed must be an exact match with an existing record, across all parameters.

trans-unit.source: Removing the last record from a record set does not delete the record set.
trans-unit.target: Removing the last record from a record set does not delete the record set.

trans-unit.source: See [Delete a record set](#delete-a-record-set) below for more.
trans-unit.target: See [Delete a record set](#delete-a-record-set) below for more.

trans-unit.source: Remove AAAA record from a record set
trans-unit.target: Remove AAAA record from a record set

trans-unit.source: Remove CNAME record from a record set
trans-unit.target: Remove CNAME record from a record set

trans-unit.source: Remove MX record from a record set
trans-unit.target: Remove MX record from a record set

trans-unit.source: Remove NS record from record set
trans-unit.target: Remove NS record from record set

trans-unit.source: Remove SRV record from a record set
trans-unit.target: Remove SRV record from a record set

trans-unit.source: Remove TXT record from a record set
trans-unit.target: Remove TXT record from a record set

trans-unit.source: Delete a record set
trans-unit.target: Delete a record set

trans-unit.source: Record sets can be deleted using the Remove-AzureDnsRecordSet cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Record sets can be deleted using the Remove-AzureDnsRecordSet cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You cannot delete the SOA and NS record sets at the zone apex (name = ‘@’) that are created automatically when the zone is created.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You cannot delete the SOA and NS record sets at the zone apex (name = ‘@’) that are created automatically when the zone is created.

trans-unit.source: They will be deleted automatically when deleting the zone.
trans-unit.target: They will be deleted automatically when deleting the zone.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, the A record set "test-a" will be removed from contoso.com DNS zone:
trans-unit.target: In the example below, the A record set "test-a" will be removed from contoso.com DNS zone:

trans-unit.source: The optional ‘-q’ switch can be used to suppress the confirmation prompt.
trans-unit.target: The optional ‘-q’ switch can be used to suppress the confirmation prompt.
